occurrences.line_text: And certaine of the theeues there by them left,
Ne any left, that victorie to him enuide.
Bedeaw'd with teares there left it in the place:
Yet left not quite, but drew a litle space
Departed life, and left vnto them all.
During his absence left in heauy care,
In which he many massacres had left,
Who now no place besides vnsought had left,
Him liberty was left aloud to rore:
And smote off quite his right leg by the knee,
Her other leg was lame, that she no'te walke,
Sometimes her staffe, though it her one leg were,
But all that leg, which did his body beare,
By meanes his leg through his late luckelesse prise,
And yet the one her other legge had lame,
And of legierdemayne the mysteries did know.
The Romane legion in dreadfull fight:
Emongst the Angels, a whole legione
Legions of Sprights, the which like little flyes
Which swarming all about his legs did crall,
And her streight legs most brauely were embayld
Whiles his long legs nigh raught vnto the ground;
Or creepe betweene his legs, so in to goe,
And both her feete and legs together twyned
And on her legs she painted buskins wore,
And th'armes and legs of three, to succour him in fight.
His sonne king Leill by fathers labour long,
Ne lend we leisure to his idle toy:
Now a loose Leman to vile seruice bound:
And me thy worthy meed vnto thy Leman take.
Als his faire Leman, flying through a brooke,
Franckly each paramour his leman knowes,
To be his Leman and his Ladie trew:
By any Ladies side for Leman to haue laine.
A leman fit for such a louer deare.
His Leman from the Stygian Princes boure.
Did poure into his Lemans lap so fast,
To serue his Lemans loue: for he, by kind,
Great Ptolomï¿½e it for his lemans sake
Would change his liking, and new Lemans proue:
To lay his spoiles before his lemans traine:
Which had no loue nor lemman there in store,
And wrought in Lemno with vnquenched fire:
But tlo him leaping, len him such a knocke,
That to affections does the bridle lend;
To them, that list, these base regardes I lend:
In vaine therefore, Pyrrochles, should I lend
That boy them sought, and vnto him did lend.
Or who shall lend me wings, with which from ground
But let that same delitious Poet lend
That but if she did lend her short reliefe,
Ne lend we leisure to his idle toy:
But she thereto would lend but light regard,
Through hunger long, that hart to him doth lend,
To lend an eare, and softly to relent.
And vnto Ladies loue would lend no leasure:
Ne lend an eare to ought, that might behoue,
That to old Loncaster his name doth lend;
To see an helpelesse euill, double griefe doth lend.
That powre he also doth to Princes lend,
The third day came, that should due tryall lend
Thereto great helpe dame Nature selfe doth lend:
To lend him day his better right to trie,
Both horse and armes, and what so else to lend,
But if ye please to lend me leaue a while,
Did care a whit, ne any liking lend:
Fearing least he at length the raines would lend
But to her cry they list not lenden eare,
In stead of rest thou lendest rayling teares,
For lending life to me a wretch vnkind;
For strength, and wealth, and happinesse she lends,
For heauen that vnto all lends equall eare,
The earth to all her creatures lodging lends.
And lends vnto it leaue the emptie ayre to beat.
Now needeth him no lenger labour spend,
He left him lying so, ne would no lenger stay.
Then forth she rose, ne lenger would abide,
Vnto his maister, he no lenger would
Her hoped pray, she would no lenger bide,
Why do ye lenger feed on loathed light,
Them list no lenger there at leasure dwell,
That wofull louer, loathing lenger light,
The lenger life, I wote the greater sin,
He staid not lenger talke, but with fierce ire
Why liuest thou, dead dog, a lenger day,
For lenger time, then that, no liuing wight
After so wicked deed why liu'st thou lenger day?
But Ã´; great pitty, that no lenger time
She it surrendred, ne her selfe would lenger vex.
To make there lenger soiourne and abode;
For nothing would she lenger there be stayd,
The wisard could no lenger beare her bord,
Whose Empire lenger here, then euer any stood.
Ne lenger stayd for th'other to reply,
And that perforce, for want of lenger light,
He then did put, her pleasures lenger to partake.
She lenger yet is like captiu'd to bee:
He woxe, that lenger he note stand vpright,
Astraea loathing lenger here to space
He list no lenger to vse lothfull speach,
She saw it vaine to make there lenger stay,
And would no lenger treat, but bad them sound.
To make there lenger stay, forth on his iourney goth.
Would not permit, to make their lenger stay,
And could no lenger beare so great abuse,
The matrone stayd no lenger to enquire,
At length it brought them to a hollow caue,
Were stretcht now forth at length without entraile.
At length they chaunst to meet vpon the way
And oft her kist. At length all passed feare,
Till that at length she found the troden gras,
Which hardly doen, at length she gan them pray,
So well they sped, that they be come at length
His tayle was stretched out in wondrous length,
Loe where your foe lyes stretcht in monstrous length,
Till that at length with Archimage they meet:
At length they came into a larger space,
Nigh a speares length behind his crouper fell,
At length they came into a forrest wyde,
And sighing sore, at length him thus bespake;
Till that to the sea-coast at length she her addrest.
At length allay, and stint thy stormy strife,
Beyond his croupe, the length of all her launce,
So long she trauelled, till at length she came
At length he spide, whereas that wofull Squire,
Thus she at length perswaded him to rise,
At length they both vpstarted in amaze;
The which for length I will not here pursew,
Till that at length vpon th'appointed day,
At length when as he saw her hastie heat
That at the length vnto a bay he brought her,
At length did marke about her purple brest
Till that at length into that forrest wide,
At length they spide, where towards them with speed
At length they came, whereas a troupe of Knights
At length breakes downe in raine, and haile, and sleet,
Since of my loue at length I rest assured,
So Artegall at length him forst forsake
That at the length he has yrent the dore,
At length found out, whereas she hidden lay
Till that at length nigh to the sea they drew;
The sunne at length his ioyous face doth cleare:
To whom he thus at length. The tidings sad,
At length he saw the hindmost ouertake
Till that at length she did before her spie
Then two speares length; So mischiefe ouermatcht the wronger.
She suffred, yet at length she did requight,
An huge great Beast it was, when it in length
Till nigh vnto the place at length approcht he has.
Who came at length, with proud presumpteous gate,
Nathlesse at length him selfe he did vpreare
At length it chaunst, that both their hands on hie,
At length bespake; What meanes this, gentle swaine?
At length breakes forth, and brode displayes his smyling hew.
He drenched was, she at the length dispacht him,
Till that at length, in his extreamest neede,
So that at length, after long weary chace,
At length he heard vnder the forrests syde
At length, when as no hope of his retourne
Till that at length vnto a woody glade
Till that at length nigh tyrd with former chace,
Aboue a launces length him forth did beare,
Yet thus at length he said, How now Sir Knight?
Fearing least he at length the raines would lend
He at the length was slaine, and layd on ground,
At length when they occasion fittest found,
At length espyes at hand the happie cost,
At length a Shepheard, which there by did keepe
At length into a Monastere did light,
doth lengthen her sonnes liues.
But had he beene, where earst his armes were lent,
To me he lent this rope, to him a rustie knife.
And take away this long lent loathed light:
More rype vs reason lent to chose our Peares,
But if she had her least helpe to thee lent,
Nathelesse so sore abuff to him it lent,
What dismall day hath lent this cursed light,
The Palmer lent his eare vnto the noyce,
And catching hold of him, as downe he lent,
And lent her wary eare to vnderstand,
Yet both full liefe him lodging to haue lent,
Yet she to none of them her liking lent,
But yet his sisters skill vnto him lent
And vnto rest themselues all onely lent,
Vnto abuse of lawlesse lust was lent,
But she, whose hart to loue was wholly lent,
Vnto whose trust the charge thereof was lent:
To cure her sonne, as he his faith had lent:
So courage lent a cloke to cowardise.
And altars vnto him, and temples lent,
To which whilest she lent her intentiue mind,
And to his Lord Sir Artegall it lent,
Then to his first emprize his mind he lent,
Hath he her lent, a Champion to prouide?
And new life to her lent, in midst of deadly feare.
And that bright sword, the sword of Iustice lent,
So soone as passage is vnto him lent,
Saue such as sudden rage him lent to smite,
He lent against a tree, that backeward onset bard.
That euer I this life vnto thee lent,
And how that he in lieu of life him lent,
But to him stepping, such a stroke him lent,
A little well is lent, that gaineth more withall.
Proud Tarquin, and too lordly Lentulus,
From leprous mouth on all, that euer writt:
Which when the valiant Elfe perceiu'd, he lept
Lept fierce vpon his shield, and her huge traine
He to him lept, in mind to reaue his life,
And lightly lept from vnderneath the blow:
How without stop or stay he fiercely lept,
Into the lake he lept, his Lord to ayd,
Did shut, and from behind it forth there lept
Octauius here lept into his roome,
She lightly lept out of her filed bed,
Hurling his sword away, he lightly lept
Rudely to her he lept, and his rough hand
He lightly lept out of his place of rest,
He to her lept with deadly dreadfull looke,
But he it seeing, lightly to him lept,
In gentle thewes, and such like seemely leres.
Long fostred in the filth of Lerna lake,
More loathd then Lerna, or then Stygian lake,
Ne would be taught with any termes, to lerne
And eke th'enchaunter ioyous seemd no lesse,
And him no lesse, that any like did vse,
If lesse, then that I feare, more fauour I haue found.
And had he lesse, yet some he would giue to the pore.
The falsest man aliue; who tries shall find no lesse.
Nath'lesse th'Enchaunter would not spare his paine,
And I (said Braggadocchio) thought no lesse,
Yet seemd no lesse to loue, then loued to bee:
And that my falser friend did no lesse ioyous deeme.
Losse is no shame, nor to be lesse then foe,
Nath'lesse now quench thy whot emboyling wrath:
She no lesse glad, then he desirous was
Nath'lesse most heauenly faire in deed and vew
Nath'lesse the Prince would not forsake his sell:
Walkt round about the world, and I no lesse,
Nath'lesse the same enioyed but short happy howre:
No lesse, then rockes, (as trauellers informe,)
Yet that, which reft it, no lesse faire was fownd:
That fairer seemes, the lesse ye see her may;
All losse is lesse, and lesse the infamie,
All losse is lesse, and lesse the infamie,
Her entertaynd; nath'lesse she inly deemd
Nath'lesse those feends may not their worke forbeare,
No whit lesse faire, then terrible in fight:
Nath'lesse to thee thy folly I forgiue,
With no lesse haste, and eke with no lesse dreed,
With no lesse haste, and eke with no lesse dreed,
Yet she no lesse the knight feard, then that villein rude.
That fast she from him fled, no lesse affrayd,
What can I lesse do, then her loue therefore,
Who no lesse carefully her tendered,
That it she shund no lesse, then dread to die,
That all the sorrow in the world is lesse,
And said; Sir knight, your cause is nothing lesse,
To loue faire Daphne, which thee loued lesse:
Lesse she thee lou'd, then was thy iust desart,
Hath no lesse griefe endured for your gentle sake.
Who her deare nourslings losse no lesse did mourne,
She that no lesse was courteous then stout,
Ne lesse approued was Cambelloes might,
Ne lesse his skill in weapons did appeare,
Against so many no lesse mightie met,
No lesse then death it selfe, in daungerous affright.
In no lesse neede of helpe, then him he weend.
She lesse esteem'd, then th'others vertuous gouernment.
Ne lesse thereat did Paridell complaine,
Vntride, is lesse then when thou shalt it try:
That mou'd Belphebe her no lesse to hate,
And in conditions to be loath'd no lesse:
Then lesse (said she) by all the woe I pas,
No lesse then perfect gold surmounts the meanest brasse.
No lesse did Daunger threaten me with dread,
And valiant hearts, in thoughts lesse hard and bold,
No lesse then do her elder sisters broode.
Sith no lesse famous then the rest they bee,
Now lesse she feared that same fatall read,
Ne lesse was she in secret hart affected,
His dreadfull heast, much lesse him match in fight,
And was of no lesse vertue, then of fame.
For ere thou limit what is lesse or more
Ne is the earth the lesse, or loseth ought,
It is no lesse beseeming well, to beare
Ne lesse did Talus suffer sleepe to seaze
And much lesse honour by that warlike kinde
Nath'lesse that stroke so cruell passage found,
Whom like disguize no lesse deformed had,
And of all other weapons lesse or more,
That they the whiles may take lesse heedie keepe,
All perill ought be lesse, and lesse all paine
All perill ought be lesse, and lesse all paine
And so be now Grantorto, who no lesse
Yet spake she seldom, but thought more, the lesse she sed.
Which I no lesse disdayning, backe returned
And of lesse liuelood and hability,
Did yeeld; Ne lesse the Lady did aduaunce.
Yet now no lesse encombrance she did see,
Ne she lesse glad; for she so wisely did,
Yet no lesse thankes to you for your good will.
But Calidore, though no lesse sory wight,
Ne lesse in vertue that beseemes her well,
Ne lesse in hart reioyced Calidore,
No lesse did tender the faire Pastorell,
Yet hoping griefe may lessen being told,
Yet is the stocke not lessened, nor spent,
For nought may lessened nor enlarged bee,
And his worke lessened, that his loue mote grow:
Yet sithens silence lesseneth not my fire,
The lesser pangs can beare, who hath endur'd the chiefe.
Like Hesperus emongst the lesser lights,
That it should not deface all others lesser light?
But to be lesser, then himselfe, doth marre
That in thy selfe thy lesser parts do moue,
So huge a mind could not in lesser rest,
Amongst the lesser starres in euening cleare.
They soone would loath their lesser happinesse,
That doth enlumine all these lesser fyres,
That all the rest like lesser lamps did dim:
All other lesser lights in light excell,
(A lesson hard) and make the Libbard sterne
This dayes ensample hath this lesson deare
A harder lesson, to learne Continence
A lesson too too hard for liuing clay,
Need teacheth her this lesson hard and rare,
That she may hearke to loue, and reade this lesson often.
So fond a lesson, as to loue againe.
Made her companion, and her lessoned
Of loue full manie lessons did apply,
Lest she with blame her honor should attaint,
Tho looking vp vnto the cry to lest,
(Let none them read) thereof did verses frame,
Let me not dye in languor and long teares.
Ne let vaine feares procure your needlesse smart,
Let fall her eyen, as shamefast to the earth,
O leaue her soone, or let her soone be slaine.
And let her in; where of his cruell rage
The Lyon frayed them, him in to let:
Let not his loue, let not his restlesse spright
Let not his loue, let not his restlesse spright
Let now abate the terror of your might,
Or else goe them auenge, and let be seene,
The mother of dread darknesse, and let stay
That fainting each, themselues to breathen let,
Whilest Satyrane him from pursuit did let:
Now let the stony dart of senselesse cold
And let eternall night so sad [sight] fro me hide.
Ne let it seeme, that credence this exceedes,
But wofull Ladie let me you intrete,
Scorning the let of so vnequall foe:
He downe let fall his arme, and soft withdrew
Ne let that wicked woman scape away;
Now in your powre, to let her liue, or dye.
But spoile her of her scarlot robe, and let her fly.
They let her goe at will, and wander wayes vnknowne.
A wide way made to let forth liuing breath.
But God you neuer let his charmed speeches heare.
Or let him die, that loatheth liuing breath?
Or let him die at ease, that liueth here vneath?
Why wilt not let him passe, that long hath stood
Whe[n] houre of death is come, let none aske whence, nor why.
Is not his law, Let euery sinner die:
Ne let vaine words bewitch thy manly hart,
Ne let the man ascribe it to his skill,
O let me not (quoth he) then turne againe
But let me here for aye in peace remaine,
But now a while let downe that haughtie string,
To let them downe before his flightes end:
Let vs deuize of ease and euerlasting rest.
Let nought be hid from me, that ought to be exprest.
But let that man with better sence aduize,
He may it find; ne let him then admire,
Let one word fall that may your griefe vnfold,
To let a wearie wretch from her dew rest,
Her deare besought, to let her dye a mayd.
But let them still be bloudy, as befell,
That downe they let their cruell weapons fall,
To let him weet his doughtie valiaunce,
Dotard (said he) let be thy deepe aduise;
Perdie (said Trompart) let her passe at will,
Let vs soone hence depart. They soone agree;
Assur'd, ere long the truth to let me vnderstand.
(Said Guyon,) let that message to thy Lord be brought.
So vp he let him rise, who with grim looke
Ne let thy stout hart melt in pitty vayne:
Crying, Let be that Ladie debonaire,
Sonne (said he then) let be thy bitter scorne,
As authour of vniustice, there to let him dye.
Ne Mammon would there let him long remaine,
The vengeance prest? Or who shall let me now,
Did breake the launce, and let the head abyde:
Let Scaldis tell, and let tell Hania,
Let Scaldis tell, and let tell Hania,
And let the marsh of Estham bruges tell,
For that their tribute he refusd to let be payd.
But let them pas, whiles wind and weather right
And therewith all attonce at him let fly
Let all that liue, hereby be counselled,
And let him heare some part of their rare melody.
And straunge phantomes doth let vs oft forsee,
Let them returned be vnto their former state.
Let Grill be Grill, and haue his hoggish mind,
But let vs hence depart, whilest wether serues and wind.
But let that same delitious Poet lend
To sing his mistresse prayse, and let him mend,
Ne let his fairest Cynthia refuse,
But either Gloriana let her chuse,
The Prince of grace, to let him runne that turne.
Let not thee grieue dismounted to haue beene,
To let not others honour be defaste,
Let later age that noble vse enuie,
And so did let her goodly visage to appere.
Let not her fault your sweet affections marre,
Faire Sir, I let you weete, that from the howre
Let be therefore my vengeaunce to disswade,
To let the secret of her hart to her appeare.
Then Glauce thus, Let not it thee offend,
And yet was loth to let her purpose plaine appeare.
Hast learn'd to loue, let no whit thee dismay
Let vs in feigned armes our selues disguize,
But if they sleepe, ï¿½ let them soone awake:
For her great courage would not let her weepe,
And let their temed fishes softly swim
Full myld to her he spake, and oft let fall
Did let him forage. Downe himselfe he layd
There let her with the damned spirits dwell,
With cruell threats, his passage through the ford to let.
The bitter earth, and bad to let him in
She did it faire dispred, and let to florish faire.
As any Nymph (let not it be enuyde,)
Ne did she let dull sleepe once to relent,
Few trickling teares she softly forth let fall,
Which would not let me be her Chappellane,
Downe in a Dongeon deepe he let her fall,
The which to let you weet, will further time require.
But neuer let th'ensample of the bad
Nay let vs first (said Satyrane[)] entreat
The man by gentle meanes, to let vs in,
So as he was not let to enter there:
She low let fall, that flowd from her lanck syde
Or therein write to let his loue be showne;
In speaking, many false belgardes at her let fly.
Good Sir, let not my rudenesse be no breach
For sith the houre, that first he did them let
To the wide world, and let her fly alone,
But let him passe as lightly, as he came:
But let vs go to seeke my dearest Dame,
To saue his life, ne let him be descryde,
O let him far be banished away,
And in his stead let Loue for euer dwell,
And leaning on his elbow, these few wordes let fly.
To better boot, but let me dye, that ought;
Rather let try extremities of chaunce,
Of secret daunger, ne let sleepe oppresse
Where let them wend at will, whilest here I doe respire.
In vaine she wisht, that fate n'ould let her yet possesse.
Which straight to her was yeelded without let.
Faire Sir, of friendship let me now you pray,
Let vgly shame and endlesse infamy
Yet would not let their battell so be broken,
That they at last their wrothfull hands let fall,
Haue I thus long thy life vnto thee let:
Let forth his wearie ghost and made an end of strife.
Or warded, or auoyded and let goe,
He can let driue at him with all his power,
The which not onely did not from him let
With heapes of strokes, which he at him let flie,
To let them passe at will, for dread of shame.
To let him loose, to saue their proper stakes;
Let neuer Ladie to his loue assent,
Did find it fit, withouten breach or let.
Ne let his speeches come vnto their eare.
Let me this craue, sith first I was defyde,
With dreadfull strokes let driue at him so sore,
He let to grow and griesly to concrew,
As was her wont, thinking to let her weet
Against those two let driue, as they were wood:
And twixt her selfe and Loue did let me pas;
By virgins, and her sacrifices let to rest.
Sometime with tender teares to let her goe,
To let faire Florimell in bands remayne,
Let them record them, that are better skild,
And let their swelling waters low before him fall.
Bewrayd it selfe, to let men plainely wot,
But let me waste in woe my wretched yeares,
Let then this plaint vnto his eares be borne,
To let her die, whom he might haue redrest.
But let me die and end my daies attone,
And let him liue vnlou'd, or loue him selfe alone.
Then let mee liue, as louers ought to do,
Such thraldome or such freedome let it surely be.
Let none then blame me, if in discipline
Let both the dead and liuing equally
What time if naught me let, I will be there
And with his iron flale at it let flie,
Well then, sayd Artegall, let it be tride.
For proofe shew forth thy sword, and let it tell,
For Braggadochio would not let him pas;
And let that losell, plainely now displayd,
